home.validationSubtitle: Every invoice undergoes rigorous validation through four technical stages, ensuring 100% compliance with EN 16931 European standard and XRechnung 3.0.2 German implementation. Our validator checks over 200 business rules and technical constraints.
home.step1Desc: Advanced vision models process your invoice document and extract all structured data fields required for electronic invoicing.
home.step1Details: The AI scans the entire document including headers, line items table, totals section, and footer. It identifies over 50 data points: seller/buyer information (BT-27 to BT-63), invoice metadata (BT-1, BT-2, BT-3), line items with quantities and prices (BT-126 to BT-131), tax breakdowns (BT-106 to BT-117), payment instructions (BT-81 to BT-84), and electronic routing addresses (BT-34, BT-49). Special attention is paid to European VAT IDs, IBANs, and multi-currency amounts.
home.step1Example: Extracted fields: invoiceNumber='RE-2024-0042', invoiceDate='2024-01-15', sellerVatId='DE123456789', buyerName='Acme GmbH', lineItems=[{desc:'Consulting', qty:8, unitPrice:125.00, taxRate:19}], subtotal=1000.00, taxAmount=190.00, totalAmount=1190.00, currency='EUR'
home.step2Desc: Extracted data is validated against 150+ business rules defined in the European standard EN 16931-1:2017, ensuring semantic correctness and business logic integrity.
home.step2Details: The validator enforces cardinality rules (mandatory vs optional fields), data type constraints (dates in ISO 8601, amounts with 2-4 decimals, country codes in ISO 3166-1 alpha-2), code list validation (currency ISO 4217, tax category codes S/Z/E/AE/K/G), and cross-field business rules. Key checks include: BR-CO-15 (sum of line net amounts + allowances/charges = invoice net), BR-CO-16 (VAT category tax amount = VAT category taxable amount × rate), BR-1 through BR-65 (core semantic rules), and BR-CL-* (code list conformance).
home.step2Example: Validated rules: BR-CO-15 ✓ (1000.00 + 0 = 1000.00), BR-16 ✓ (invoice total present), BR-S-08 ✓ (seller VAT when tax S/AE/K/G), BR-CO-9 ✓ (line net = qty × price), BR-DEC-01 ✓ (amounts max 2 decimals), BR-CL-01 ✓ (currency=EUR in ISO 4217 list)
home.step3Desc: Validated data is transformed into XRechnung 3.0.2 XML format (UBL 2.1 or UN/CEFACT CII 16B syntax), mapping all business terms and applying German extension rules (BR-DE-*).
home.step3Details: The generator creates a syntactically correct XML document following XRechnung specification profiles. All 200+ business terms (BT-1 to BT-151) are mapped to their corresponding XML paths. German extensions are applied: BR-DE-1 to BR-DE-29 (mandatory fields like seller phone, buyer country code, payment terms text), Leitweg-ID routing (BT-34-1), and IBAN validation (BR-DE-23-a). The XML structure includes cac:AccountingSupplierParty, cac:AccountingCustomerParty, cac:InvoiceLine elements with proper namespaces (urn:oasis:names:specification:ubl:schema:xsd:Invoice-2, urn:cen.eu:en16931:2017).
home.step4Desc: The final XML document is validated using the official KoSIT Validator 1.6.1 with XRechnung 3.0.2 scenarios, performing Schematron rule checks, XSD grammar validation, and technical syntax verification.
home.step4Details: The KoSIT validator runs three validation layers: (1) XSD schema validation ensures well-formed XML with correct namespaces and element structure, (2) Schematron rules (180+ assertions) verify business semantics including BR-S-02 (seller VAT required for standard-rated invoices), BR-S-04 (buyer VAT required for reverse charge), BR-S-08 (payment means code validation), and BR-DE-* German-specific rules, (3) Code list validation checks values against official code lists (ISO, CEF, UNTDID). The validator outputs a detailed report with acceptance status (valid/invalid), error location XPath, and rule violation descriptions.
home.step4Example: Validation report: acceptanceStatus='VALID', schematronErrors=0, xsdErrors=0. Checked rules: BR-S-02 ✓, BR-S-08 ✓, BR-DE-1 ✓ (seller.address.street present), BR-DE-6 ✓ (seller.phone present), BR-DE-15 ✓ (payment terms present), BR-DE-23-a ✓ (IBAN format DE89370400440532013000)

1.q: When should I choose UBL over CII?
1.a: UBL is the better choice when your recipient uses PEPPOL or has a UBL-based system (e.g., in the Netherlands, Scandinavia). For German authorities, both are accepted.

2.q: Is XRechnung UBL just as valid as CII?
2.a: Yes, absolutely. Both syntaxes are officially approved by KoSIT and fulfill EN 16931. There is no legal difference.

3.q: Can I switch between CII and UBL?
3.a: Yes. In the review step, you can change the output format at any time. The extracted data remains the same.

1.q: What's the difference between ZUGFeRD and XRechnung?
1.a: XRechnung is pure XML. ZUGFeRD is a hybrid: a PDF/A-3 document with embedded XML. You can open and read ZUGFeRD as a PDF, while XRechnung requires special software.

2.q: Is ZUGFeRD suitable for government invoicing?
2.a: Partially. ZUGFeRD with the 'XRechnung' profile is accepted by many authorities. For maximum public sector compatibility, we recommend pure XRechnung XML.

3.a: Factur-X is the French name for ZUGFeRD. Technically they are identical – both based on the same EN 16931 standard with PDF/A-3 and embedded CII XML.

4.a: Invoice2E creates ZUGFeRD at EN 16931 conformance level – the highest profile with full compliance. Factur-X Basic is also available.

5.a: Free credits on signup. After that, from €9.99 for 10 conversions. Credits are valid for 12 months.

1.a: NLCIUS (Netherlands Core Invoice Usage Specification) is the Dutch implementation of EN 16931, also known as SI-UBL 2.0. It is based on UBL and is the standard for e-invoices in the Netherlands.

2.q: Is NLCIUS mandatory in the Netherlands?
2.a: For invoices to the Dutch government, e-invoicing via PEPPOL with SI-UBL is mandatory. For B2B it is recommended and increasingly required.

3.a: NLCIUS is a national adaptation (CIUS) of EN 16931, optimized for Dutch requirements. PEPPOL BIS is the overarching European format. Both are based on UBL.

4.a: Free credits on signup. After that, from €9.99 for 10 conversions.

requirements.subtitle: NLCIUS extends Peppol BIS 3.0 with Dutch requirements: OIN/KVK endpoints and BTW format.

required.1: All Peppol BIS 3.0 required fields (see Peppol page)
required.2: Seller: OIN (scheme 0190, 20 digits) or KVK (scheme 0106, 8 digits)
required.3: Buyer: OIN or KVK as electronic address
required.4: Seller: BTW number (NL + 9 digits + B + 2 digits)

requirements.source: NLCIUS (SI-UBL 2.0) is maintained by Logius (Dutch Government).
